One of the biggest indicators for young people who may have exposure or may have the ability may have the possibility of exhibiting or developing a mental illness is family history, so if you yourself, a caregiver or someone who is related to the young person has had a history of mental illness, its important. Thats a warning sign. First what we see in these young people is a pretty dramatic change in behavior. But, first and foremost, its interesting, these young people tend to be incredibly smart. Theyre above average in their creativity, their intellect, they really stand out in a crowd. We find more often than not these young people just seem to be above average in their level of functioning, and what tends to happen is all of a sudden things start changing for them. Whats happening to the young person is, their mind starts to play tricks on them. They might see shadows. They might see images. They might see colors and lights. They might start hearing murmuring or ticking sounds or any other range of noises that are starting to come from outside of their head. They might start believing delusional thoughts about themselves, usually it tends to be more of the paranoid nature. And, they think that someones out to get them, they think that someones out to harm them. And, you know, upon kind of checking this out with them theres no reason for them to be afraid of anybody. So those signs will start to occur relatively slowly but youll see them start, sort of become more and more severe in the sense that theres a disconnect with reality around it. At one point they will have, see those shadows, hear those voices, or those, hear the sound and know theyre not real. Theyll know that somethings going on with their mind at some point, and typically it looks like a psychotic episode, they will switch over to where those things that they see and the things that they hear they will not be able to distinguish them from reality. And that is so important to catch the young people while theyre experiencing these prodromal or premorbid symptoms in order to sort of educate them. Let them know, stress is a huge factor in this. What the programs locally will help families of young people do is reduce stress because not knowing whats going on with you, if youre the child is very very detrimental. They are scared to death that someones going to find out that something is going wrong with them, and that theyre crazy. And, unfortunately with the stigma that we have in our communities, they are there just forced to not talk to anyone anybody about it. So its important for us to educate to give the information out, reduce the stress so that those signs dont get any worse. And, theres tons of hope for young people if these things are caught early. Now unfortunately you have many young people in our community that have not had the opportunity to get those signs, to be seen early, and they are experiencing significant mental illness like schizophrenia or bipolar disorder with psychotic episodes, and those young people have very have a very difficult time navigating the day-to-day life, you know, requirements; that is keeping, you know, a job or staying in school, being able to really have meaningful interpersonal relationships. So, because of all that, the mental illness that they have tends to get in the way of them getting treatment and getting help. And, so we really hope to prevent them from ever getting to that place. But we have had a lot of success in supporting those young people as well. There is a program locally thats called Catalyst program that works with young people 16 to 24 who have been diagnosed with said disorders, like schizophrenia and bipolar disorder with psychotic episodes have a history of alcohol and drug use, typically because they want to self-medicate or they have no other outs or no other options. They tend to be homeless, a history of having not succeeded in our traditional standards of care. So, catalyst really supports them in all areas of their life to be able to give them a fighting chance and some hope to be able to live to live a very fulfilling life.

Response.BaseQuestion: Lauras law has very specific nine criteria
Response.Content: Lauras law is court ordered treatment for individuals who refuse outpatient treatment or to seek services out in the community. The law in San Diego has been approved to be implemented and we are in the midst of developing those services. What Lauras law is has very specific nine criteria and these nine criteria must all be met to ensure that the individual that is being referred for assisted outpatient treatment meets all the eligibility requirements. Some of the criteria for the individual with serious mental illness, it includes that the person has not been treated in the recent past it includes that the person has been hospitalized in the last 36 months psychiatrically, or they have been receiving treatment while in jail. It includes episodes of violent behavior or aggression in the last 48 months. Those are some of the current criteria there are nine as I said before. Lauras law does not order you to take medication or force you to take medication. Certainly the judge that orders assisted outpatient treatment can recommend that the person to take medication through outpatient treatment but again that is voluntary choice.

Response.BaseQuestion: Recovery language is more than being politically correct.
Response.Content: Recovery language is person first language which is grounded in recovery. Recovery encompasses five principles which are hope, choice and accountability, empowerment, and finding a new purpose in life. And often people find that through spirituality So when I talk of recovery language, for example instead of calling myself a schizophrenic I call myself a person living with schizophrenia. Another important example is just when youre trying to communicate in recovery language you want to make sure that all of your all of the words that you use create hope in someone else. A lot of people use slang that has to do with mental illness and some of it can be really derogatory I think oftentimes people dont recognize how much words can affect other people and for that reason its important that we watch our own words, words like psycho crazy schizo Ive been called the entire gambit and so when those words come up in conversation like, oh you got crazy mad skills its kind of like pouring a little bit of hurt back into an open wound, because Ive always been called those names when I was at my worst. When people use those words to refer to me it doesnt really encourage other people to learn more or to get to know me and so for that reason I think its important that we are always looking to talk to people about people and not talk to illnesses about illnesses. Describing me you could say you could say Im an author, San Diegan or I feel down. If you just blame it on my illness it doesnt do anything to solve the problem. Saying "Sarah is schizophrenic," that just dehumanizes me. When I talk to people about not using the record the words like crazy and schizo psycho and they think, "oh so you want us to be more politically correct" and Im like no, recovery language is more than being politically correct. Recovery language goes beyond being politically correct its more content-based, for example rather than telling me that I am, I saw this crazy wild movie, why don't you say I saw this amazing movie it had awesome graphics or something of that nature. Learning how to use your words and be focused on building others.

Response.BaseQuestion: Life is so much more manageable when I work my hardest to get enough sleep.

But creating good sleep hygiene can be vital, so I really do what I can to prioritize my life around it and getting enough sleep. If that means coming home early from an activity with friends or family or just forcing myself to turn off the phone turn off the commuter computer turn off everything, all the lights, its vital. Something else that Ive learned, I need to take my medicine about 1 to 2 hours before I intend on falling asleep because only when Im able to do that am able to fall asleep on time and then get up on time the next morning. In my life, when Im starting to get less sleep. I start to recognize that life is a little bit more difficult to handle my emotions are more difficult to regulate and so when I start getting less than 8 to 10 hours for example lets say I got four hours of sleep then the next day I really have to catch up and so sometimes I need to call my doctor in order to help me get to sleep so we can adjust things because often times the things that work for everyday people dont who dont have a mental illness like mine they have no problem falling asleep however thats not the case for me I can have everything turned off and even work my hardest to fall asleep and for whatever reason my brain just doesnt go to sleep. Life is so much more manageable when I work my hardest to get enough sleep.

Response.BaseQuestion: The Internet is a lot like being in a very noisy cafeteria with a lot of people talking.
Response.Content: When I talk to seniors as a part of the senior mobile technology lab I tend to try and emphasize that the Internet is a lot like being in a very noisy cafeteria with a lot of people talking and just like a telephone where you need to be connected to the phone line to be able to make a call your computer is a lot like that connection and as soon as you connect to the Internet anyone who is a part of that conversation has a chance to look at your digital information. So its very important to not only understand that as soon as Im connected to the Internet the Internet is also connected to me. So when Im on Facebook not only am I making posts but my friends, and depending on what my privacy settings are set at, friends of friends or maybe the public can also see my posts. So one of the common scams that we keep hearing about is someone gets your information from Facebook especially if your privacy settings are set to public and then they appear as a friend or family member saying "Help I need, Im in trouble" maybe "I need to be bailed out please send me money/" Weve all heard about these scams from especially African countries who say youve won the lot of money please send me your information. So older adults definitely need to hear that you never give out your information, never give out your name, never to give out your Social Security number, and surely never give out your banking information. If youre going to do Internet banking do it in the bank other things you can do to protect yourself is on your mobile devices if youre not actually using the Internet you can turn your Wi-Fi off you dont actually have to be on if youre not using it. And the same thing for your desktop computer you can actually unplug it so that the Internet is not connected to you anymore. Some of the other things that they might want to look into is when theyre doing their email make sure that they are always getting a subject on their emails this is both when they send things out and also when they get them. One of the ways spam filters look for good emails is that theres a subject that makes sense so when youre sending them make sure you say "hey hi its Joe," or you know "hey I really enjoyed such and such." but also when you look for an email make sure that the subject makes sense and that who its from is someone that you recognize. And if for some reason you dont recognize the person you can email them back and say "hey who are you?" Another thing on Facebook just because someone tries to friend you, you do not have to friend them back. If I get a random person saying "hey I want to be your friend" I often decline it and then go to their page and email them a kind of thing saying who are you, how do you know me, why do you want to be my friend ? And thats perfectly legitimate just because someone asks to be my friend I dont have to be their friend back. And if they dont take the time to answer me a one-word thing, "oh I met you at such and such an activity and you suggested I friend you on Facebook" then theyre not worth taking the chances of your information getting out in hands that you dont want to have access to your information. We have the website its kind of in the process of being made so its not fully formed yet but we have information about where were going to be where the seniors can come and talk to us were all throughout the county. Also the NAMI website is going to have access to their tech caf information where it has wonderful links to various sites that have YouTube videos and webinars about this kind of information. But my favorite place to go to get information about seniors and technology is YouTube. If you put in their search bar "seniors and the Internet" it will bring up a ton of wonderful videos about scams or about security issues and you can learn about it there. Theres also a number of really amazing websites specifically about seniors in the Internet and theyll have hundreds of articles where you can go and read. So this information is out there on the Internet if you want to find it for your family member or your loved one. And I would say the best thing for your senior who is maybe a little shy around technology is, just sit down with them. We can go out all around the county and seniors are hungry for this kind of information they really want to learn but you know computers are pretty confusing right now and theyre very very complicated its not like they can just go and twiddle around on their own. We have seniors that come to our labs who dont know where the on button is, they dont know what double-clicking is to open up a program, so if you just sit down and kind of show them the basics then they can get a little bit comfortable and maybe then theyll be googling on their own and they can find these kind of information for themselves.

So people, their neighbors opened up the doors to the people that in the community that had a mental illness but were stable to live on their own and be able to take care of their own medications and supervision and care. So independent livings are they're not subsidize. They're homes where an individual, a landlord open their home to a person that has is seeking housing. It can be a person that has a mental illness, but it can also be for anybody that is seeking housing. But they typically cater to people with mental illness. They are found all throughout the community. Typically its a shared bedroom. And the best place to find in independent living is through the Independent Living Association because the Independent Living Association looks for the quality with homes, and because Independent Livings are unregulated, theyre not overseen by any government agency they really need to make sure that there a safe environment for your loved one to live in. And the Independent Living Association make sure that that home is a safe to live in through their tight quality standards to look for when reviewing a house. Just like any housing I would recommend that you please take a tour to the house of the house before you decide on that being a place for your loved one to live.

What I found works is listening more than telling.
Response.Content: Communicating with someone with a mental illness is a real challenge. Often in my situation family members dont want to talk, they push you away. The inclination is to try to convince them to recognize that they have an illness and that they need treatment, usually medication, to see a psychiatrist or whatever. Very often that doesnt work. So it gets more and more frustrating as you try harder and harder to get your message across. What I found works is listening more than telling. In other words, when I would go to my family member and leave my agenda outside and really try to understand what hes going through that actually helped a lot more. Because you're dealing with a person who has their own perspective and you need to respect that perspective. And the more that you can empathize, really listen deeply and empathize, the more that they trust you and upon that trust you can work together. So that is that was a lesson that was difficult to learn. Many times that I tried over and over again to say "Yes, but." But, it was only when I really listened deeply and empathized that I felt like we were communicating.

Response.BaseQuestion: That persons defenses will be lower when they feel like theyve been heard.
Response.Content: Theres a famous saying by Albert Einstein that the definition of insanity is doing the same thing over and over again and expecting a different result. So communicating with a loved one with mental illness, when you try over and over again to convince them that they have a mental illness, that they need help, if it doesnt work then you need to do something else. So when I found was, I hitting that wall and I didnt know what else to do. And so I tried reaching out. I read articles online. I read books that were recommended to me. One of the first things I did was take the NAMI Family-to-Family class, and there was a unit in there on communicating with your loved one that really helped me a lot. Another book that was recommended is a book by Xavier Amador and its called Im Not Sick I Dont Need Help, which of course Id heard many times. And it talked, in that book he talks about the LEAP method which is basically listening to what the person has to say, empathizing -- doesnt matter whether that what they have to say sounds irrational to you, or delusional, its how does that, how would that feel to them. So empathizing with them and then finding what you can agree on. Because that persons defenses will be lower when they feel like theyve been heard. And then finally you can figure out what you can partner on. So that book was very helpful. I still felt odd when I would go in to talk to my son. I felt like I was walking on eggshells and thats very common I knew he didnt want to talk about it he really didnt want to talk about any think as he was very depressed and withdrawn but I wanted to reach him somehow and I didnt know what words to say. I would actually practice sometimes before going up to talk to him and I just felt awkward. So one of the final things that I did fairly recently was I worked with a company called Helios and they are partnering with NAMI in another part of the country, they're on the East Coast. And they do videoconferencing with a therapist and its all about communicating with your loved one in the things that helped me there was they took everything that I had learned elsewhere and gave me the words to say they actually got into the details of how to phrase the question to your loved one and how to do how to ask a question how to express an interest in having them do something and so I actually started using those and yes he feel really strange because youre following a formula but the more I did it the more comfortable I felt and after about a month of doing that, nothing happens immediately you have to be patient, but after about a month of doing that my son I could tell that my son felt heard and not attacked or pressured. He felt understood and he actually came to me and wanting my help, and that was that was mind boggling. That was amazing, and wonderful.

RQ.BaseQuestion: What should I do if my loved one won't accept help?

Response.BaseQuestion: Sometimes people being open actually opens the door to finding out more about how not alone you are.
Response.Content: One of the toughest things about dealing with a loved one with mental illness is feeling alone like youre the only one going through this, that nobody is going to understand this. The stigma makes it impossible, makes it feel impossible to talk about. And there are people in your life in your life that will not understand. There were friends of mine that I knew just didnt get it when I started to try to explain and sometimes family members dont understand. What I did in that situation was I reached out to support groups and also to the NAMI Family-to-Family class. And as I did that I met other people who were going through the same thing. And when you do that you dont feel alone and you realize that this is not uncommon. There are a lot of people out there who are going through the same thing. I went to a workshop once and the woman gave some advice which was very helpful, and she said you may actually have to drop some friendships or cool some family relationships because if they are arent supportive then theyre not helping. And you, for your own health, you may need to ease or to cut off those relationships. And I actually did that with one friend. And I needed to and I felt better after that. And I replaced that friendship with others, with people from support groups and others that really did understand. So I dont feel alone anymore. And the other thing is that once you, at least I began to talk a little bit more about it, I found that when I was more open about what I was dealing with people would come to me and say oh me too, Ive never told anybody this before. You would be amazed at how many people you know, you already know that are going through, that have a loved one with mental illness, or they're struggling with mental illness and they just never told anybody. So sometimes people being open actually opens the door to finding out more about how not alone you are.

Response.BaseQuestion: How do you take care of yourself?
Response.Content: When I first started dealing with my sons illness and going to support groups going to classes people were constantly saying to me what you doing to take care of yourself my answer was its not about me its about my son I have to fix him. I have to figure out how to fix them. And they kept coming back to, "well, but what about you?" And eventually I learned that it really was about me. That if I didnt take care of myself, I wasnt to be of any use to anybody else. And its like that old, well is not so old, but they talk about in the flight instructions we you get on a plane in the case of an emergency in the oxygen drops mask drops you put on yourself first before you put it on your children. So you have to take care of yourself and I, so I started focusing on what I could do for myself I needed to have a life again. And I took up gardening it was one of the things that Id never garden before. And I actually found that there are a lot of lessons that I learned in gardening that were applicable to the situation in my family. One was I had to tomato plants to start with, by the way of a terrible gardener I never did get very good at it, but started with two tomato plants, bought them for the same price in the same kinds of pots, put them right next to each other. I watered them exactly the same. I fertilized them exactly the same, everything was the same. And then one day about a month later I remember taking a look at them seeing them from a distance and noted that one was thriving and the other one was struggling to survive. And I started to cry because I saw my two sons and at that moment I realized that it wasnt my fault. I was able to let go of that. I had raised my sons the same and that this illness that struck my younger son was not his fault, it wasnt my fault. So that was a major lesson to learn. The other lesson I learned from gardening was a lesson about hope. After the tomato season was long gone, and this was, I grew many tomato plants but six months later they were all dead and gone, it was the winter and tomatoes dont grow in the winter, but I went outside one day and in the corner of my yard, in a barren part of my yard, there was a tomato plant growing. And I hadnt planted it, I hadnt watered it and this thing was growing. And it was healthy and it had tomatoes on it. And I looked at that and I said theres always hope. The things that, that was impossible. And again I looked at that and I thought theres no reason not to hope that my son can, can do things that we think now are impossible. So those are my lessons from the garden.

Response.BaseQuestion: Just because you get older, doesn't mean you'll have mental health challenges.
Response.Content: So with older adults is pretty common to think that as we get older its a natural process for everyone to have mental health challenges, But thats not necessarily the case. Some older adults are fine throughout their life and even in their later years, of course they may have some transitions were they may have some ups and downs, but it may not impact them severely. There are going to be other individuals who have struggled with depression or other forms of mental illness throughout their entire life and they also experience it later in life. Theres a third group of individuals who may have been fine through most of their adult years, but as they get into their older adult years they face certain losses or certain health challenges which may lead to some mental health challenges.

RQ.BaseQuestion: Mental Illness in Older Adults Overview

Response.BaseQuestion: Link between physical challenges and mental illness
Response.Content: Older adults often face many physical challenges as they get older. They may have problems with mobility, they may have chronic conditions such as a heart condition or diabetes, all of which may have some impact on how theyre feeling and thinking. Some of them may have a direct relationship such as diabetes, because diabetes, when your sugar level is low, then it also impacts your mood. So there is a relationship. You may also see some individuals who have problem with a stroke that may also lead to some depression. But, it doesnt mean that all physical disabilities or all physical challenges cause mental illness. But certainly there is a stronger relationship with somebody who has physical challenges to also potentially have some mental health challenges. One example would be a person who has some mobility issues; maybe they were an athlete in their younger years then they had a hip fracture and they werent able to go out and see their friends as often as they could. And certainly anybody in that situation would have some challenges unless they had a friend, unless they had a family member who could still take them out to their usual social activities to the market to wherever they needed to be.

RQ.BaseQuestion: What is the relationship between physical and mental illnesses in older adults?

Response.BaseQuestion: Suicide risk in older adults
Response.Content:
The suicide risk in older adults is quite high. There are reports that suggest that older adults are at the highest risk, particularly white males. There are also other reports that suggest that they are the second highest group, first being young adults. In either case, this is something that one needs to pay attention to, especially as older adults become more isolated; perhaps their spouse or their partner becomes deceased or maybe they just dont have a lot of friends or family around, not a big social group. And thats really one of the things that needs to be monitored, is how active are they in their community, how active are they physically, even spiritually. Are they taking care of their diet and things like that? So those all point to depression and as depression becomes more severe thats when a suicide becomes more at risk.
One other thing to think about with suicide risk is that a lot of older adults, because many of them have either chronic conditions or some other kind of health conditions, they are taking a variety of medications. Some of these medications may be overused or misused. And some individuals may take those medications incorrectly in combination with alcohol which puts them at a higher risk. So those are all things to take into consideration with older adults and suicide.

RQ.BaseQuestion: What is the risk of suicide in older adults?

Response.BaseQuestion: Family members are very important with supporting older adults with mental illness.
Response.Content: Family members are very important with supporting individuals, older adults with mental illness. And, once again we need to think about, has this older adult experience mental illness throughout their life or is it their first time? If its really their first time experiencing a mental health challenge, then the family member really wants to bring it to attention to that loved one. Most likely the loved one will try to minimize it and say "oh no, its not that big of a deal." But what would be helpful is going with them to a doctor's appointment and explaining to the doctor or to the nurse, "this is what Ive seen in my mom or dad. Im really concerned. He or she says he feels fine, but they actually, they stopped eating, they start, dont see their friends anymore, they dont go to church anymore, the house is a mess, they stop paying for the bills," and things like that. So really explaining that to a medical professional. And, you know, also directly asking the medical professional, "do you think this person needs to see a mental health professional for a screening for depression or mental illness?" You know, its totally okay to ask for that, because sometimes some medical professionals need that nudge. And actually thats where most of our older adults will go to seek treatment first, is that they will feel comfortable in going to a medical professional, they will feel less comfortable going to a traditional mental health clinic.

RQ.BaseQuestion: What is NAMI's In Our Own Voice program?

Response.BaseQuestion: Many older adults don't have the language for describing what they're feeling.
Response.Content: Sometimes its difficult to diagnose mental illness in older adults because many older adults dont really have the language for describing what they're feeling. They grew up in a culture where people were told to keep things to themselves. They were told to keep feelings to themselves. So the only thing that they feel, that they do feel comfortable and talking about is how theyre feeling physically: my back aches, my head aches my stomach aches. To be able to say comfortably, especially to the stranger, "I feel sad," "I felt sad for the past, you know, three months," or, "I hear things that other people dont hear." That really brings a lot of shame to individuals. And you know as part of the aging process we all feel our bodies changing in a lot of different ways, so it's also easy to just say its a part of being older, I guess this is just how it is. And so thats where its very difficult to really pinpoint where, you know, what is the cause of it. You know, socially they see other seniors who have experienced losses and they think that thats just part of the norm, so thats where it makes it difficult to see whats happening.

Response.BaseQuestion: Family members of older adults also need support.
Response.Content: Family members are an important part of an older adult getting treatment and succeeding in treatment. But one thing to keep in mind is that family members themselves may be older adults. And so they might be the one trying to be the strong one, where they themselves might also be kind of in a closet in terms of hiding their own concerns about their loved one, and this process that theyre going to. So they also need some support. So some key things to think about, just in general, is having some kind of a structured schedule. Having a structured schedule in terms of meals, medications, making sure you go to the doctor regularly. And then social activities, making sure that that there is that regular contact with family, friends, church, whomever, you have some social contact with. And that really helps in providing a buffer. Response.BaseQuestion: Certain rights can never be denied
Response.Content: The rights for a patient in a hospital setting are often, in many cases, the same for an involuntary patient, as they are for voluntary patient. There are certain rights that, by law, can never be denied. For example, you must be able to be treated with humane care, dignity, and respect. You have a right to religious freedom and practice. You have a right to be free from discrimination. Those rights can never be denied. However, there are some rights that are afforded to patients by law that can be denied, if they are being used in a way that is dangerous to others. These are rights that involve being able to wear your own clothing, being able to receive visitors, being able to use the phone. And there are others as well. These rights,if they are being used in a way that they are injurious to either the patient or to others on the unit, then it may be that those rights can be denied temporarily. Additionally, as a patient in a hospital receiving care, the patient has a right to refuse medical treatment, and to refuse psychiatric medication, if the patient does not want to take medication. And there may be a separate hearing that will be held to decide whether or not the patient has the ability to consent or refuse that medication. If the patient has been placed on an involuntary hold, there will be a due process hearing that will be held within a very short time of the hold having been placed. And, the patient always retains the right to request a writ of habeas corpus and to be able to go downtown and be heard in front of a judge.

RQ.BaseQuestion: What are a person's rights under an involuntary hospitalization?

Response.BaseQuestion: A hospital is required to start providing discharge planning from the moment the patient arrives.
Response.Content: A hospital is required to start providing discharge planning for a patient in the hospital from the moment the patient arrives. Hopefully by the time the patient has been discharged there are several options and referrals that are being made available to the patient at the time the patient is leaving the hospital. However, the patient does retain the right, as a free individual, to not follow up on those services. We would hope, of course, that anyone does follow up on services that are helpful. If an individual is on a conservatorship, specifically in LPS conservatorship, it may be that some of their rights have temporarily been given to a conservator; rights involving decisions on where the individual can be placed, and rights on what medication the individual must be taking, among others. However, if you are not on LPS conservatorship, an individual is free to go from the hospital and make whatever choices they think are in their best interest.

RQ.BaseQuestion: What happens after a person is released from involuntary hospitalization?

Response.BaseQuestion: The law always provides for voluntary treatment as preference.
Response.Content: The law allows that certain individuals can be hospitalized against their will if they are meeting certain legal criteria. The three legal criteria are danger to self, danger to others, and grave disability. All of these criteria need to be due to a mental disorder. So someone is presenting with certain behaviors that are dangerous to themselves or others, or they are unable to provide for their own basic needs of food, clothing, and shelter, and they are resistant to treatment, they may be brought into a hospital involuntarily. This may be done by law enforcement who is authorized by law to bring individuals in under whats called a 5150, or someone whos in an emergency department or receiving care in a health facility may be placed on involuntary hold and treatment may be provided against the individuals will. The law always provides for voluntary treatment as preference, and if you are in a facility or loved one is in a facility who wants to be there voluntarily that information should be communicated to treating providers, and or patient advocacy, and all efforts will be made to switch that person to a voluntary status if that applies.

RQ.BaseQuestion: What will happen if I call 911

Response.BaseQuestion: We have the opportunity to have a clinician on scene to help.
Response.Content: The Psychiatric Emergency Response Team, better known as PERT here in San Diego, is a team that is made up of a law enforcement officer or deputy and a licensed clinic clinician. A licensed clinician for PERT can be a registered nurse, a licensed social worker, a licensed marriage family therapist, or licensed psychologist. The purpose of the PERT program is to pair law enforcement and mental health together in that police car and respond to calls that are a mental health crisis. The value of having PERT respond to these mental health calls that have come to the attention of law enforcement, is that law enforcement is the agency or the system that responds to the emergency call, but once that scene is safe, we have the opportunity to have a clinician on that scene to help support the officer and more importantly help support the client and the family. To assess the mental health crisis, to provide referrals, and if necessary to support in a transportation to the most appropriate mental health facility that that client is going to need.

RQ.BaseQuestion: What is a psychiatric emergency response team? (PERT)

Response.Content: A PERT clinician is assigned to a law enforcement officer. When somebody is having a mental health emergency, whether its a family member calling on behalf of their loved one, or the client themselves experiencing the mental health emergency, What happens is that we pick up the phone, we call 911, that goes into a law enforcement system. And so, a dispatcher will receive that phone call and dispatch out an officer or deputy to respond to that mental health crisis. So, regardless of the mental health emergency, if youre calling 911 you will get a law enforcement response. PERT places clinicians with officers and deputies so we can support, not only the law enforcement agency that received the mental health call, the mental health emergency, but we can support the client at the point of contact. Prior to PERT, prior to all the mental health training that PERT has provided to our law enforcement officers and deputies throughout San Diego County, law enforcement was often asked to evaluate the emergency as it was on the scene, and then transport a person to an appropriate facility. Here, when we have a PERT clinician on the scene, that clinician is able to assess, have access, when appropriate, to mental health records, be able to communicate with the client and make sure that that client's wishes and family member's wishes are adhered to, when appropriate, and make sure that the client is transported to the most appropriate level of care. Hospitalization may not be the appropriate level of care, but PERT can and will access other resources throughout the county, and make sure that that those client's needs are being addressed, that of come to the attention of law enforcement. So to recap, if you are calling 911, if you are asking for support on a mental health emergency, you will get a law enforcement response. Please ask if a PERT unit is available, and if we have a unit available, we will do our best to also respond to that call. But you will always get that law enforcement call first, that officer on that scene.

Response.Content: As a psychiatrist I diagnose mental illness based on primarily the history that the patient that the patient gives me in the initial interview, but also the history as it happens over time. So when I meet a patient I want to hear about not only how they are experiencing symptoms now, but how theyve been experiencing symptoms for many years, sometimes 5,10 years ago. For instance, with depression somebody could have depressive symptoms first and then anxiety symptoms, or vice versa.
